raw_text:
UK rebate 'unjustified' - Chirac
 
 French president Jacques Chirac has called the UK's £3bn rebate from the European Union "unjustified".
 
 Speaking after a summit meeting he said unless it was put up for discussion the EU would never be able to reach agreement on its medium term finances. Earlier Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said the UK was prepared to veto any bid to reduce the rebate secured by Margaret Thatcher in 1984. He said it remained justified because less EU farm money came to the UK.
 
 Mr Chirac told reporters in Brussels: "One can only have a reasonable budgetary balance if we put back on the table the British cheque. It can no longer be justified. It was from the past." But a UK Government official responded: "Even with the rebate, the UK pays two and a half times more than France contributes to the EU budget. Without it we would pay 14 times as much as France. "There can be no deal on future financing which does not protect the rebate."
 
 The 25-member EU is gearing up for tough negotiations on its budget plans for the period 2007-2013, with the bloc's Luxembourg presidency hoping to strike a deal at a June summit. Earlier Conservative Graham Brady said the rebate was a "crucial test" of how firmly ministers were prepared to stand up for Britain. EU Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso has indicated he wants the rebate to come to an end. Mr Straw said that as well as the veto over the rebate the UK wanted to keep a tight rein on national contributions.
 
 The UK, France, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands and Sweden want the EU budget to be capped at 1% of member states' combined national incomes - the European Commission has urged an increase to 1.26%. Mr Straw has said the EU commission's proposal would mean a 35% hike in the budget. Shadow Europe minister Mr Brady said: "I believe it is essential that Britain keeps the rebate and I think it's a crucial test of how firmly the British government is prepared to stand up for Britain internationally in Europe.
 
 "The UK is already one of the biggest net contributors to the EU ." The foreign secretary meanwhile said the "justice" of the rebate remained. "We have one of the lowest net receipts of any EU country because of the relatively small size of our agriculture sector and its efficiency. "That continues to be the case."
 
 UK Independence Party leader Roger Knapman said the rebate was "set in stone" and there was no reason to negotiate about it. "It is extraordinary to do it at this time, just as we are becoming the biggest contributor to the EU. If we lose our rebate as well, the British taxpayer is going to be bled at such a rate that I think everyone will go off the European project." EU leaders are holding talks in Brussels on how to re-energise the sluggish European economy. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is meeting his EU counterparts to finalise a package of measures aimed at stimulating growth and boosting employment ahead of a series of referendums on the European Constitution. The plans could introduce a free market into everything from computer services to construction. Critics - including Germany and France - believe liberalisation could result in companies shifting staff to cheaper bases in Eastern Europe, undercutting large EU economies and undermining social protections. There are also concerns about the number of workers from eastern European countries who will head west, exacerbating the already high unemployment levels in Germany.
 
 Mr Straw insisted there was nothing to fear from the services directorate. "European countries overall have benefited hugely from the free market in goods," he said. "What we are now talking about is developing that market into an internal market in services." Britain's low unemployment meant there was less "neurosis" about people coming from eastern European countries. "In countries like Germany and France, where frankly because of a tighter social market they have much higher levels of unemployment, there is increasing anxiety about other people coming in," he said.
llama3.2:1b: UK rebate 'unjustified' - Chirac: President Jacques Chirac has called the £3bn rebate from the EU "unjustified" and said it would be difficult for the EU to reach agreement on its medium term finances unless it is put up for discussion.
Foreign Secretary Jack Straw says the UK pays 2.5 times more than France in farm contributions, but with the rebate, the UK would pay 14 times as much as France if it were not included.
EU Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso wants the rebate to end and has indicated a proposal to cap the EU budget at 1% of combined national incomes.
The UK, France, Germany, Austria, Netherlands, and Sweden want the EU budget to be capped at 1%.
Shadow Europe minister Graham Brady says Britain should keep the rebate and believe it's essential for maintaining an open position in international relations.
llama3.2:3b: UK rebate called unjustified by French President Chirac; UK refuses to reduce £3bn rebate secured by Margaret Thatcher; UK will veto any bid to reduce the rebate; EU budget negotiations set for June summit; EU wants rebate to end, but UK seeks protection of rebate and tight rein on national contributions.
gemma2:2b: Jacques Chirac criticizes the UK's £3 billion rebate as unjustified and calls for its removal from EU budget discussions.
The UK government defends the rebate, arguing it remains justified due to lower farm payments received by the UK compared to France.

While the EU seeks a deal on future financing with capped contributions at 1% of member states' combined national incomes, the UK advocates for maintaining the current rebate and tight control over contributions.

Various parties within the EU are facing off on budget proposals and strategies for stimulating the sluggish economy, leading to discussions regarding liberalisation in service markets and its potential impact on employment levels across Europe.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
UK rebate 'unjustified', French president Jacques Chirac calls it 'unfair'

French President Jacques Chirac criticizes the UK's £3bn rebate from the European Union as "unjustified".
Speaking after a summit meeting, he says unless the EU is given discussion on the UK's medium-term finances, the EU would never reach an agreement.
Former Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said the UK is prepared to veto any bid for a reduction of the £3bn UK rebate signed by Margaret Thatcher in 1984.
He says it remains justified because less EU farm money came to the UK.
EU leaders are meeting in Brussels on how to re-energise the European economy.
UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is meeting his EU counterparts to finalise a package of measures aimed at stimulating growth and boosting employment ahead of referenda on the European Constitution.
Critics believe liberalisation could result in companies moving staff from Eastern Europe, which would lead to unemployment, while undermining social protections.
Chirac states there's nothing to fear from services minister: "Europe overall has benefited greatly from free market goods."
qwen2.5:1.5b: French President Chirac criticizes UK's £3 billion rebate as unjustified due to reduced EU farm money contribution from the UK compared to France.
EU leaders are gearing up for tough negotiations on 2007-2013 budget plans, aiming to end UK rebate and increase EU budget to 1.26% of member states' national incomes.
qwen2.5:3b: French President Jacques Chirac has criticized the UK rebate from the EU as unjustified, stating that without discussion on this issue, the EU cannot agree on its medium-term finances.
The UK argues the rebate remains justified due to less agricultural funding reaching the UK.
UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw asserts the rebate is still necessary to prevent disproportionate financial contributions compared to France.
However, EU Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso suggests ending the rebate.
Conservative MP Graham Brady sees it as a crucial test of British stance in Europe.
The UK wants to maintain the 1% budget cap, while EU officials advocate for an increase to 1.26%.
Critics like Roger Knapman and Germany/France argue this could lead to economic instability due to potential outsourcing and increased unemployment.
Tony Blair is planning to implement free market measures within the EU, which has raised concerns about labor mobility and social protections in affected sectors.
opencoder:1.5b: UK rebate 'unjustified' - Chirac has called the UK's £3bn rebate from the European Union "unjustified".
Following a summit meeting by Jacques Chirac, Mr Chirac pointed out that unless it was put up for discussion, the EU would not be able to reach agreement on its medium term finances.
The former said it remained justified because less EU farm money came to the UK as a result of Margaret Thatcher in 1984.
After the meeting, Mr Straw clarified that it remained justified because of the balance between present government spending and future national contributions from foreign governments.
The former noted that without the rebate, the UK would have had to pay two and a half times more than France.
The latter said there was no need for further discussions on future financing which prevented the rebate.
However, as they stressed, it could mean a 35% hike in the EU budget.
With Mr Graham Brady's permission, the former wanted to keep a tight rein on national contributions to the EU.
The former stressed that despite its size, the rebate was essential for maintaining a healthy balance and stability in the European Union.
smollm:1.7b:
The UK rebate - unjustified - - Chirac
 
 French president Jacques Chirac has called the UK's £3bn rebate from the European Union "unjustified".
Speaking after a summit meeting with EU leaders, Mr Chirac said unless it was put up for discussion the EU would never be able to reach agreement on its medium term finances.
Earlier Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said the UK was prepared to veto any bid to reduce the rebate secured by Margaret Thatcher in 1984.
He said it remained justified because less EU farm money came to the UK.
Mr Chirac told reporters in Brussels: "One can only have a reasonable budgetary balance if we put back on the table the British cheque.
It can no longer be justified."
But a UK Government official responded: "Even with the rebate, the UK pays two and a half times more than France contributes to the EU budget.
Without it, the UK would pay 14 times as much as France."
The 25-member EU is gearing up for tough negotiations on its budget plans for the period 2007-2013, with the bloc's Luxembourg presidency hoping to strike a deal at a June summit.
Mr Chirac said that as well as the rebate, the UK wanted to keep a tight rein on national contributions.
"The UK is already one of the biggest net contributors to the EU ," the foreign secretary added.
"If we lose our rebate as well, the British taxpayer will be bled at such a rate that I think everyone will go off the European project."
EU leaders are holding talks in Brussels on how to re-energise the sluggish European economy and boost employment ahead of a series of referendums on the European Constitution.
The UK's net contribution to the EU budget is currently around £150 million per year, but it has been declining steadily since 2007 as the UK's economy has grown faster than other member states'.
Critics - including Germany and France - believe liberalisation could result in companies shifting staff to cheaper bases in Eastern Europe.
There are also concerns about the number of workers from eastern European countries who will head west, exacerbating unemployment levels in those countries.
The UK's net contribution to the EU budget is currently around £150 million per year, but it has been declining steadily since 2007 as the UK's economy has grown faster than other member states'.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK's £3 billion EU rebate called "unjustified" was criticized by France's Jacques Chirac and the UK's Jack Straw, who prepared to veto a Brexit proposal that secured 1984's rebate.
The UK pays two and a half times more than France in EU budget contributions.
Chirac emphasized the need for the UK to pay only its share of national income, fearing it would cause economic restructuring.
Meanwhile, the EU seeks a 1% cap on budget growth and aims to prevent labor migration from Eastern Europe to Britain.
Concerns about unemployment persist as European countries face challenges in hiring workers there.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK's rebate from the European Union has been called unjustified by French officials and the Foreign Secretary in response to EU proposals for a budget cap on national contributions.

The EU President, Jose Manuel Barroso, has urged the UK to keep its £3 billion (€4.2 billion) rebate, but the UK's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, is meeting with his counterparts in Bruxelles to finalize a package of measures to stimulate growth and boost employment ahead of referenda on the European Constitution.
Critics believe liberalization could result in companies moving staff to cheap locations in Eastern Europe, undercutting large EU economies and undermining social protections.

The Prime Minister, Gordon Brown, has urged the UK government to be firm with its demand for a budget cap on national contributions, arguing that Britain is already one of the biggest net contributors to the EU's budget.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK rebate 'unjustified' - Chirac, a French president, has called the UK's £3bn rebate from the European Union "unjustified."
He believes that less EU farm money comes to the UK because it is not as efficient and should be reduced.

This is in line with his country's foreign policy of remaining one of the biggest net contributors to the EU, even though Britain's agricultural sector has a relatively low efficiency compared to other European countries.
The French government has expressed similar concerns about the UK's rebate and urged them to keep their contributions at 1% of member states' combined national incomes.
phi:2.7b: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is meeting EU leaders to finalise a package of measures aimed at stimulating growth and boosting employment ahead of referendums on the European Constitution.

The plans could introduce a free-market into everything from computer services to construction, which has led to concerns about companies shifting staff to cheaper bases in Eastern Europe and the negative impact it will have on large EU economies.
Critics also believe liberalisation could result in workers being brought over from eastern European countries at the expense of local job opportunities.

However, UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw insists that there is nothing to fear from the services directorate, as Britain's low unemployment means less "neurosis" about people coming from eastern European countries seeking employment.

The official added that although the EU commission has proposed a cap on the EU budget at 1% of member states' combined national incomes, the UK wants to keep a tight rein over national contributions and maintain the rebate secured by Margaret Thatcher in 1984.

However, a UK Government official pointed out that with the rebate, the UK pays two and a half times more than France contributes to the EU budget.
The issue of the rebate is significant as countries prepare for negotiations on the EU's budget plans for 2007-2013.

The UK, France, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands, and Sweden want the EU budget to be capped at 1% of member states' combined national incomes, while the European Commission has urged an increase to 1.26%.

UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw defended the rebate, secured in 1984, arguing it remains necessary due to the UK's lower share of EU farm subsidies.
The UK government stated that even with the rebate, the UK contributes significantly more than France.
The EU is preparing for tough budget negotiations for 2007-2013, with some countries pushing for a budget cap at 1% of national incomes, while the European Commission seeks an increase to 1.26%.
Conservative and UK Independence Party leaders stressed the importance of maintaining the rebate.

stablelm2:1.6b: French President Jacques Chirac called the UK £3bn rebate from the EU "unjustified", as Foreign Secretary Jack Straw stated that unless it is put up for discussion, the EU will never be able  to reach an agreement on its medium-term finances.

UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is meeting his EU counterparts to finalize a package of measures aimed at stimulating growth and boosting employment ahead of several referendums on the European Constitution.
Critics believe liberalization could result in companies shifting staff to cheaper bases in Eastern Europe, undercutting large EU economies and undermining social protections.
granite3.1-dense:2b: French President Jacques Chirac criticized the UK's £3 billion rebate from the European Union as "unjustified," stating it hinders agreement on the EU's medium-term finances.

Earlier, UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw vowed to veto any reduction of this 1984-secured rebate, arguing it remains justified due to less EU farm money reaching the UK and the UK paying two and a half times more to the EU budget than France.
The 25-member EU is preparing for challenging negotiations on its budget for 2007-2013, with Luxembourg's presidency aiming to finalize it at a June summit.

The UK, along with France, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands, and Sweden, advocates for capping the EU budget at 1% of member states' combined national incomes (currently suggested by the European Commission as 1.26%).

Straw emphasized that such a cap would result in a 35% increase in the budget, while critics like UKIP leader Roger Knapman believe the rebate should remain intact to protect British taxpayers from excessive contributions and potential job losses due to EU liberalization.
UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is meeting EU counterparts to finalize measures aimed at stimulating growth and employment ahead of European Constitution referendums.
Critics, including Germany and France, express concerns about the potential influx of workers from Eastern Europe, which could exacerbate high unemployment rates in their countries.
Straw countered that Britain's low unemployment levels provide less anxiety regarding this issue.
